root: ^“Hello again, don’t suppose you’ve heard any word in regards to my missing persons case?”
^The desk hasn’t exactly been too busy with briefcase wielding guests. No rogue literature has been miraculously recovered.
^“With that lovely news now confirmed, I’ll be expecting a call. Please forward it to my room.”
^“Of course, but I’m going to need to take down a name, Motel policy.”
^He seems briefly annoyed at this personal intrusion. You can’t help but be a little excited at the chance to gain more information on this scenario.
^“Fine. It will be coming from an associate of P. Pleasant Publishing.”
^“They will be wanting to hear about my current…situation."
^"Hopefully the disappearance of my Manager will overshadow any anger over my little side trip.”
^He pauses to sigh. Doesn’t seem like this vacation is going very smoothly.
^“Oh, and if Aubrey does somehow manage to call, please tell them I am very disappointed in their directional abilities and we will be exchanging strong words.”
^Despite the anger evident in his voice, he seems oddly pleased about the loss of Aubrey.
^“Might be worth breaking the bad news yourself in advance. Getting lost along with my latest bestseller is not a good look for them.”
^“After our little chat has concluded, they are most definitely fired.”
^You can’t deny being intrigued by this turn of events. Unlucky Aubrey… or judging by the sudden undertone of glee in his voice, maybe they deserved it.
^ “So… Press Manager, huh? What was Aubrey like?”
^“I’ll let you know if anyone calls!”

manager1: ^“Former Manager, would be a more polite way to phrase it now, I suppose.”
^“Whilst I do hope nothing bad has befallen them, I must say that it is a rather fortunate turn of events they won’t be staying during my holiday.”
^“It was already a chore convincing them to let me come here for a couple days at all.”
^“We often do not get along, even at the best of times. Opposing views on genre and such. ”
^“They bend to my publishers every whim. This incident will not do wonders to improve relations with them.”
^“Especially if Aubrey happens to find their way here after all…”
^“Also… they were very… how can I phrase this politely… loud.”
manager2: ^“Thank you. I wouldn't suspect it would be before tomorrow morning, but just in case.”
job: ^“It’s really important I deal with this as soon as possible as it could put some strain on my career when I return from this little trip.”
^“Was it not obvious from my previous statements? I’m an author, but I prefer to use the term novelist.”
^You can’t help but laugh at his hubris. Are they really that recognizable?
^“Come to think of it, your name does ring a bell.”
known1: ^“I rather think it should! M. Mothman is a household staple.”
^“For connoisseurs of historical fiction, that is…”
^“I’ve written such classics as ‘The Dawning of the Lamp’ and ‘Beyond the Forest Trees Part 2 featuring new Addendums'."
^“In fact, right at this very moment I’m working on my greatest work yet!
^“...which is completely a secret… why on earth am I telling you?!”
^You decide to let him keep spouting book related words at you as he goes into a frenzy trying to cover up what he just let slip.
^None of the titles instill any sort of recognition whatsoever.
known2: ^ He stares at you in mock offence. Silent. This is awkward…
^“You must be lying. I can’t believe it! Either that, or you have no taste.”
^“It seems I’ve come to expect that from this reception.”
^“Never heard of me… honestly, I’m a multi award winning bestseller. Look me up.”
sc2end: ^“Anyway, enough about my inimitable career. I have a fresh manuscript to review in my room that suddenly seems infinitely more interesting than this conversation. Adieu.”
^Well, he sure is a 'conversationalist'. Make sure to keep an eye out for any phone calls.
